titleStmt.title: To the Dean of St 08. Patricks

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Sṛ
Don't Think these few lines which I send a Reproach
From My Muse on a Car to Your Muse in a Coach.
The Great God of Poem delights in a Car
Which makes him so Bright, that We see him so far
For Were he mew'd up in a Coach 'tis allow'd
We shou'd see him no more than We see thro' a Cloud
You know to Apply this, I do not disparage
Your Lines, but I say they're the Worse for the CariageNow first You deny that a Woman's a Sive
I say that she is.──What reason do You give?
Because She lets out more than she takes in.
Is that Your Advance for't? You're still to Begin
Your Major and Minor I both can refute
I'll Teach You hereafter with whom You dispute
A Sieve keeps in half, deny't if You can
D: Adzucks I gramercy, who thouht of the Bran?
I tell you in short Sṛ You shou'd have a Pair of Stocks
For thinking to Palm on Yṛ Friend such a Paradox.
Indeed I confess att the Close You grew better
But You Light from Your Coach when You finish'd yr Letter:
Your Thing which You say wants Interpretation
What's Name for a Maiden the first Man's Damnation?
Adam's Hell, a Damzell, ay there I have hitt it,
Just as you conceiv'd it, just so I have Writt it.
Since this I've discover'd I'll make You to know it,
That now I'm Your Phoebus, and You are my Poet.
But if You Interprett The Two Lines that follow,
I'll again be Yṛ Poet, and You my Apollo.
Why a Noble Lord's Dog, and My school-house this Weather
Make up the best Catch when they're coupl'd together.
Tho: Sheridan. 973-002D
